content.description:
A rising traverse under the small overhang across the face.  Climb the first short corner to the small overhang.  Move out right and follow the line of the overhang to the 2nd to last short corner that leads up.  Climb the corner and face on the left to the top and make a belay at a pine tree.

The rock beyond this last corner looked pretty questionable so Alan made a turn and went straight up.  That said, there is some questionable rock throughout.  Good placements can be had but it's definitely not G-rated.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Bring long slings to extend and limit the rope drag.
content.location: Find the big, right-facing corner of Two Iron Shot and move right about 15 ft.  Begin off the blocks just below the face.

climbs.name: Two Iron Shot
climbs.fa: FA US Army circa 1944; FFA Andy Weinmann/Alan Goldbetter 18SEP2021

content.description:
Surprisingly nice, easy climb.  Start beneath the big, right-facing corner.  Climb the corner past ample gear placements to the overhang, move out right and around the overhang and up to the top.  Continue up and slightly right to a good size tree and belay.  At this point you're just a short distance off the trail.

Descend either by turning right on the trail and walking down the trail to the large pine with rap rings or walk-off up to the left and finding the main West Face Trail that leads back down to the Stairmaster.

We named it Two Iron Shot because there's two old iron pins on it (one is a ring pin and the other an old blade) and underneath a root of the belay tree at the top there is golf ball!  WTH?!?!
content.location: Find the upper entrance to the Old Hemlock Grove.  The climb is just around to the right from the obvious shallow crack of Organically Inclined, which splits a steep wall.

content.description:
Once cleaned up, this is probably a nice TR problem.  The FA team noted it was "a good free solo".

Find the crack, climb the face and crack using whatever methods of levitation you have. It tops out on a flat ledge and there are some TR options possible here.

Walk off left and back down to the Stairmaster.
content.protection: If anything, micronuts (brass) and very small cams.
content.location: Find the upper entrance to the OHG area by topping out the steps of the Stairmaster and walking up to the flat area.  Look to your right and find a faint trail (cairn might be there) leading to a steep wall with an obvious shallow crack.  This is the line.  You might be able to get some micro-protection in there now that wasn't available in 1983...but not much.

content.description: A nice route that burns a little at the start, stays on you a bit longer than expected, but leaves you feeling pretty mellow...kinda like good moonshine.  Start in the back of the square-cut corner, boulder up, and rail out the nice rising finger crack to the arete.  Turn the corner to the left, move to the next little corner, then up left onto the face and past the tree.  Continue up on easier, somewhat slabby terrain to the top and the pine-tree rap station.
content.location: In the middle of the Old Hemlock Grove area, walk up and right, scrambling on the slab up to find a square-cut corner with an obvious finger crack that rises out to the arete.

content.description:
This line goes up the crack in the first overhang, then move right and pulls the hard moves up and further out right.  You get a nice handjam and rest at this point.  Follow the crack up the face above, past a final bulge to the pine tree belay/rap station.

As with Flying Circus, this is sporty and sustained line.  The gear is a bit better though.
content.location: As you enter the Old Hemlock Grove from just off the Stairmaster, look for two low arches in the rock curving in opposite directions.  The route begins in the middle of the right arch (shared with Flying Circus).

climbs.name: Flying Circus
climbs.fa: FA Mitchell Wood, John Campbell, Sean Maisel 1981

content.description:
This line goes up the crack in the first overhang, then pulls the hard moves in the second overhang and moves out left.  You get a sorta stance here but don't think it's over.  Follow the flared crack up the slabby face above, past a final bulge to the pine tree belay/rap station.

A sporty and sustained line.  The gear is a little sparse when you get past the second roof and into a flared crack...right where you don't want it to be sparse.
content.location: As you enter the Old Hemlock Grove from just off the Stairmaster, look for two low arches in the rock curving in opposite directions.  The route begins in the middle of the right arch.

climbs.name: Candy Andy's Corner
climbs.fa: FKA: Andy Weinmann and Alan Goldbetter, 18SEP2021

content.description:
A burly and difficult start leads to a great rest and easier climbing above.  Start to the right of some long, right-curving overhangs, directly below a triangular block with an off-fingers crack on the left...the block forms part of a short, open-book feature.

Climb up to the block and then up the crack to a really nice flat stance.  Move up and left, following a logical diagonal line to the V-notch in the overhangs and up to the top.  There are several good pines at the top you can use for a belay.

The real difficulties are in the first 15-20 feet (pretty sustained), but it protects well...if you can get your hands free.
content.location: As you enter the Old Hemlock Grove area, this is one of the first routes you'll look directly at.  Left of the route are some long, curving overhangs come out from a right-facing corner.  The route starts directly below a large triangular block with a nice off-fingers crack on the left.  There is also an old pin above and right of the block.

content.description: Climb up the crack and slab to the first roof.  Traverse left to the corner and pull the roof.  Move up the corner to the next roof and pull the 2nd overhang.  Continue up and out to the left over the final overhang and on up to the top.
content.location: Walk into the main Old Hemlock Grove area and continue to scramble up a short slab to a skinny ledge/walkway beneath the overhangs.  Continue down to the slabs on your left and look for an old ring pin in a short, right-facing corner on the slab.  Start at a crack that's just a bit left of the pin.
